pubStmt.avail:
THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.projDesc: See the project description in the corpus header for information about the British National Corpus project.
encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

s.w: It gets going and I'm at I actually was
A lot of people do that a
Yeah, but he does talk broad Yorkshire!

ptr.w: It's like er who were it?

s.w: He goes none of those northeners!
But Charlie's Scottish and I've saving bags of money, you know.
You don't think they talk like that.
You talk how you talk, and that's it.

ptr.w: Yeah, but I mean they're not just you know, just well off, he are well well off!

s.w: He worked at Lincoln don't he?
to my mother's in Lincoln he used to
always say to me go on, say summat.
You should have heard what they were doing to him.
They were right rotten to him!
You know, when Donny lost against Lincoln?
Well they were up the road from Donny and they .
We always said that he had a yellow belly!
He had summat to pick up, so they picked up
I'm all for getting er tape recorder.

ptr.w: He had to chuck in summat.

s.w: I'll tell you what he's after.
Yours don't have Sellotape all over it.
I had taxi driver on it this
Oh you did taxi driver did you?
And I says to him, you're not supposed to use this entrance.

ptr.w: Er I told him about the other one.

s.w: They're sending a different one every bloody week!
I'm spending week after week after week.
Why don't the one driving the week before tell the one the week after that they've got to go in drivers' entrance and not in bloody one!
Thingamabob nearly got run over this morning!
Sometimes she talks to you, sometimes she don't.
Wait till she tells her husband she nearly got run over.

ptr.w: That young lad coming on a bike.

s.w: And I'm going to car I thought you idiot!
Yeah, she's was a copper's wife.
Her hair's cut like that, she gotta have it cut.
And she pushes a pushchair and she's got a little lad about ?
But I don't think you've ever seen her cos you always come about ten to.

ptr.w: If it's the one that I mean

s.w: I know what I meant to ask you.
Why do you come for that alarm?

ptr.w: It was a, he bought it he's not selling that one.

s.w: He's selling the Widgie He's got a Widgie a posh
Yeah, he's got a posh one which the rest of the alarm he's putting with that.
He bought it for that erm er her
What, did she have it on t'?
He bought it for the Astra.
Yeah but, she says she bought it him for Christmas.
Well he says he bought it.
So I don't know who bought it.
I were gon na take out of that too.
Well he's still got Astra then?

pause.w: Well Marie just said that he'd got it.

s.w: Cos I says, you have seen it in passing.
Maggie's still having trouble with that.
Apparently, they keep getting er this erm what was it?
Bill phones up says, can I speak to somebody?
And I says, er I'm sorry they're not available at the moment.
You see, they've got a card of the fella that did the thingy so, when they put him onto this other fella he says, er, yeah, his name were Mr so and so.
So, they says, well I'll tell you what we'll try and find this Mr so and so, and, we'll get in contact with you.
So, he waited in for two days nothing!
So, he's rang every day since and he keeps getting this person, that says er er, we'll pass your message, we'll pass your message, we'll get back to you, I'll get back to you.
I says, you know what you want to do now?
I says, you want to phone up and say look, I want to speak to someone in authority and I want to speak to him today!
Because, if not, I'm going to see my solicitor in the morning, cos if you won't speak to me, you can speak to him instead!
I says, and I bet they call you back.
Well er, wha er what has done about it then?

pause.w: But I said, just threaten with solicitors then.

ptr.w: You can't understand anybody signing summat and not reading it can you?

s.w: Maggie wears glasses, but she won't outside.
Nearly two hundred quid he paid for a pair of glasses and she sat on them didn't she?
Well I don't give a damn what I look like in bloody glasses.
In fact, , I feel naked without bloody glasses on now.

ptr.w: If I've got to wear them, I've gotta wear them!

s.w: I don't put them in my bag.
It is, I know, I do this just get legs out of bed and
As soon as I get my legs out of bed, that's first thing I pick up, my glasses.

ptr.w: I'll tell you what it ain't exactly
That's so as you can watch it looking at telly!
And I was a young men in my prime!

s.w: Well he's got someone to talk to his while
I expect you'd be alright if he talked back to you.
I thought he was gonna take the rest of this off.

pause.w: Yeah, you blank er bits off.

s.w: I've got headphones and everything so you can come back to a certain and take it
to leave swearing and all that on.
And she says to leave swearing on.
She says, but if you listen to it, and then if you don't think that should be there you can go over it.

ptr.w: Bloody than listen to them myself.

s.w: No, Flo come I stopped her conversation half way through.

ptr.w: No, if I'd have cut time they wouldn't hear no conversation!

s.w: Cos you can gather as soon as Paul gets in I think I was asleep.
he sat up last night, he sat up last night we was gonna watch the ten o'clock movie on telly with me.
Cos it finishes at half eleven, so I says to him, oh great!
You're not working tomorrow you can watch movie wi me.
So I got my cushions and I laid here and he got his cushions and he were laid there and he says to me, are you taping this?
I says, no I'm gonna watch it.
I thought he's going to sleep again.
Quarter past ten, turned round, snoring away!
Paul we were dreaming last night.
But sh I've been, I work out, I feel .
I get in 't car, and it's warm so I end up switching heater and winding window down.
When I get in here there's nice fire.

ptr.w: Then, he were being a pig last night.

s.w: I says to him, with him breaking down other night his dinner went to dog.
The night before I kept it hot, and hot, and hot, and hot, and by time we did get it at quarter to eight I says to him, oh this is horrible, this!

ptr.w: So last night, I thought, I won't do anything till he comes in but we'd got company and er, they went outside, they were having a look at car engine and that, telling us what were wrong, you know.

s.w: And, so I says to him d' ya fancy going to fish shop?
So he decided he wanted chips, pie, curry, loads of scraps and bread and everything and he eat every bit of it up!
I bet you get as fat as a pig!
Well he says, said to me I don't know why you're going to keep, er th to slimming thing cos you, because I can't tell no difference with you.
Said it's a waste of bloody money going!
You used to have two buck teeth but you haven't now.
You know, before you couldn't see your thingy that
You're going to National Tyres on North Bridge.

pause.w: And they're going to balance your wheels.

s.w: I don't know about checking and balancing, I just says balancing.

ptr.w: Can you get insurance to pay for it?

s.w: It's four pound something a wheel there.
well they says to go there, get an invoice take it into the insurance and they will send us a cheque back out.
Usually, when they balance your wheels they they check the tracking.

ptr.w: I phoned up put Maggie on t' phone, told her sa tell her what this bloke had said and, they said, just a minute, that they'll get in touch wi insurance and phone us back.

s.w: Well they phoned back and they said, can you tell your husband to take his car to National Tyres er, that insurance has sent him, and could they give him an invoice for the insurance company.
them an invoice, he's got to take the invoice into insurance
they will deduct that off the value
send us it, and they can have the rest.
Well they won't give him it straight away, they'll see to you first.
But I says, that they were, I, that he weren't satisfied when it were vibrating and that.
And he says, gerrit checked or summat.

pause.w: So he's gonna ask them what he does about the vibrating.

s.w: National Tyre, I don't think they'll do bonnet.
Wish we'd never heard of car dealers.
spoke to since then, they says, why the heck didn't you say summat?
You shouldn't have took it there!
One fella were told they did his erm summat to his engine and it blew up didn't it?
Er, Dennis, who we were talking to last night, he says, you must be absolutely mental!
He says that his mate bought a car from there and, he were a undecided about this clocking this time, what's, what call it?
He'd er wound the clock back thirty thou.
But you know on his log book, last person that had the car he went down to see them, and they told him that it were thirty thousand over from when they sold it.

ptr.w: Yeah, but when they got it, you don't have to ask for owt er, M O T.

s.w: He went tosee person who selt it.
Might have got old M O T.
And, they were on, more on about that.
I says, you don't hear a word about anybody till you go.
Well, I mean, look at me, me with my motor car
I mean, it hadn't done all th as many miles .

ptr.w: Actually, it's not been on t' road.

s.w: I mean, you tell somebody that and they're forced to believe you are you?
Well that mini, we got it from Hutchins.
wants two more miles on my clock and I've done a thousand mile on my .

ptr.w: I was looking at it other day.

s.w: I I'm doing a thousand mile a week!
I know, but well mine's a W registered, yours is a D!
I only go a fair way.
I only do Irene's on it, and that's my lot.
Well you, I mean to say that I've had mine a long time and you ain't done much mileage on it.
Well mine's according to my log book there's three on it.
and I've had it three year.
And I ain't done, I ain't got it to a thousand yet.
But, it's all ready for M O T now.
Supposed to take it in for M O T.
Well mine ain't been used for three month.
They'll get a bit of the an holiday round here sometimes, you never know, might be able to come down.
Well, if you're in knock before you go and start it.
Well if I come down and see Steve and Kelly !
There's a story of mine can't go away.
He says, we've got in caravan.
I shouldn't have asked should I really!
Did I just give him some money, I didn't did I?
I was gon na give him cheque book and then I thought, no.
I tell you summat, if I don't get one of them bags off of .
Er, cos she come today and she says forgot book.
Aye, if I don't get one of them bags she'll not no, I'll can't get no more.
There's plenty of folks don't either.
She did up to moving but she lived at Anthorpe and she's not mentioned it since, so I'll have to ask her if she does Avon.
Cos I used to get it off of her.

pause.w: He's got a hump.
She says she's only five bags didn't she?

s.w: She's not allowed five bags, she's got to have an order of five bags.
One for hersen, and four other people.
I thought she might have five.
No, if she ain't got five bags then, the what you call it?
I thought she said well I'm allowed five bags.
Er an Avon bag actually I got er three bags with Avon.
Yeah, a shopping bag that's alright

ptr.w: I've got like a fly bag, a blue one.

s.w: well mine's whi it's a yellow bag.
I got, a shopping bag, that were a creamy colour with wi A's all over it.

ptr.w: The handbag is navy blue, with white on, and it's, like little navy blue dots on it.

s.w: Let's have a look, I don't think I've got that one.
I've got umbrella, a blue one.
I got oh I got a what they call an' all!
You know when er, you're going on away or on t' beach or summat and you put your toiletries in and you can put a towel and that?

ptr.w: Like you brought Caroline for her, cos she's literally to cut Paul's hair.
I got her one of them.

s.w: What I do is, I roll a towel up and that, and put, take them down on t' beach, you know, cos I could put my purse in and that.
Er it's got handle at head int it?
She can put her, her cutters in.

pause.w: Cos she had them in a plastic bag.

s.w: I call them a beach bag, but it's not.

pause.w: It's like a

s.w: Cos Steve got one and I got one.
I got a blue one and he got a black one.
Yeah, I got a black one.
I lent it Steven and that were it!

pause.w: You know, it sounds I spent .

s.w: D'ya know, he stuck in all day Wednesday.

ptr.w: Well it past half past ten, you think he'd be up and getting ready for work.

pause.w: He don't know his dad's in this morning.

s.w: He'll go out and get that five to ten bus or five past ten bus.

pause.w: Cos I've upset his girlfriend!

s.w: I told him he'd better tell his friends, or his girlfriends, that when they call at our house if they don't give names, they're not talking to him!
I says, cos I haven't the faintest idea who they are.
I've says your Mark, I says, he always says, is that Mrs?
Will you ask Steven if I can talk to him please?
And, there's one called Gavin, he rings up, and the girlfriend, he did have, whether it's still same one, I don't know called Sarah.

pause.w: Well, I says to him, I'm getting sick of these calls cos you don't know if it's for him or him.

s.w: And er I picked it up other night, says, can I ta speak to Steven?
So she di still didn't say her name!
So, she says, will you give Steven a message?
Talk to him when you see him.
Well will you ask Steven to call me back?
She give me no telephone number, no name nothing!
And I still didn't know who it were.
I thought, if I keep saying no she'll say, well it's Sarah or whoever but, no chance!
Just washed my eyes, I can see now.
We had a struggle this morning coming out, my windows were all mucky outsi go it got, a car, van had passed me.
I put my window washers on and my windows froze up!

ptr.w: Yeah but it didn't seem as though it were freezing though did it?

s.w: coming home last night, I stopped half way
home bloody needed checking the lights!
Keep flashing me to say that I've got my headlights on so I, when I, I give them flash back to say no I haven't.

ptr.w: When I've been taking Paul to work in the morning they've been giving me flashes and then if I, you know, flashed them back they haven't put their headlights on so I thought oh bugger yous!

s.w: He's got six lights up front.
Paul, I says, your lights aren't set properly!
I says, yeah but it's passed its M O T for lights.
He's just had to alter them hisen!
Somebody, if they were wrong you'd think they'd tell you wouldn't you?
But there's no mention of lights!
I sent mine, I took that it was out.
I said give us screwdriver, I'll do it here and now.
I says, well it seems daft taking it back, to fetch it back.
He said, I'm not failing you on it.
I said no, but yo you've got your marks on your wall I said I can cha do it now.
But this one I can do mesen.
Dipped lights though, it's just like a guess.
Not if I've got it set.
Yeah, they're just like headlights mine is.
I've got the same, but usually I have eight on front of car.
So I says, Paul, I says, get me some spotlights.
That's what's missing ont front of ours.
When he crashed we've not had anything replaced.
Cos, before you crash we had six lights on t' back and we had eight on t' front.
Cos he's got them four headlights with
the either side, then below the bumper thing, we had the fog lights and above the bumper we had two spotlights.
Now, on the back I bought him some extra fog lights for back and I bought him them fog lights that goes int window.
the light int window, and on bumper and fog light.
He come back, we've got headlights on t' front two fog lights and we got brake lights on t' back.
I says, to him, there's six lights missing off here.
I says, they cost me over two hundred quid, I says, for the six lights!
But, them at Car Care turned round and says, it's not on t' invoice.
All we keep getting off them is I says, you mean to say, we're paying two and half thousand pounds worth of repairs, I says, and they're not done?
And then when we went for wheel balancing told us to take it back for balancing and tracking, they turned round and says we're not doing it.
So I says to Maggie, we'll phone insurance, I put her on t' phone, and she said he were, he were right clever with her!
And er that's why they haven't got in contact and that.
So he, took it back before and put brand new bonnet that they've put on.
And he says, when he gets it up to sixty mile an hour on t' motorway it's still vibrating.

So, he's gonna go int insurance this morning, tell them that er bonnet's still vibrating and they've supposed to have done it twice and that, because of er ask them where he can take to have all these repair jobs done.
Cos, he went in there summat to do wi headlights or summat, one were like up and down or summat.
And he went in and he said they haven't even bloody welded this!
I says, you're alright, I said, front radiator's gonna bleeding drop off!
So he's gonna see about that this morning.
I says to him, take a day off work for, I says, for God's sake!
So you were saying, he's only upstairs just now.

ptr.w: Could you fetch my keys from upstairs please?

pause.w: Kath's got a lot of bags hasn't she?

s.w: Do you know, fellas, who'd have them?

ptr.w: One minute, she starts collecting one thing then you start collecting another thing Christmas, he come home with one of them.

s.w: That lad at work, that John what they call him?

ptr.w: And er he's got hundreds of them apparently.

s.w: So he's decided he wants to collect them now.
That was the er, last one that she'd seen they said that .
I said to Maggie I says, Steve's collecting cars I says, it don't matter if it's int box or not, I says, if they're int box they're staying in a box.
I says, and I'm buying him a rack for the ones not in a box.
With Tetleys tea now you send away and get a like a little minibus thing.
We don't get Tetleys teas though.
We don't get that at all.

ptr.w: I've just got enough for one, er one car.

s.w: He says, there's not much point in getting P G or Tetleys from one tea bag and making four
Cos what he does, he puts a tea bag in a cup pours about that much water on takes the tea bag out and tops it right up with water so he can see bottom of cup.
And then he uses same tea bag again.

ptr.w: Well that Tetley tea bags taste strong though.

s.w: One tea bag does me and Paul.

pause.w: That's all we put int teapot, one tea bag.

s.w: Well that's good that Tetleys tea stuff.
I'm sure you do get a a
Cos you never do do you?

pause.w: It's been there a fortnight and I keep asking everybody if they want to try it.

s.w: And I told Steve to drink it, and he says no, and wi you mentioning Tetleys and I don't
You have been in my bag again!
I haven't been in your bag!
I have not been in your bag!
So, in that case, you've dropped it.
I picked it up and it were th the er strap got the wrong way round.
So I had to pick it all up.
And how come he's good enough to go the Sea Cadets but he's not good enough to go college?
Because he don't go till half past ten this morning.
But I know Tetleys tea bags er one tea bag does me and Paul.
And I have it stronger than what this coffee is.
You'll have to save it till Paul comes back for the car .
I've got enough for one car for mesen.
Will you save some more and then you can send for
a gonna save me some Tetley tea tokens for a car.
Cos she has Tetleys, and we don't.
Just give her that tea, it's Tetley tea.

ptr.w: And if you don't like it you can keep the jar.

s.w: I don't know whether you do with like
Cos Jack does and all cos he's got one.
In fact, I'm gonna get his present.

pause.w: Well it's not even a proper bloody jar is it?

s.w: That's what it says, if you don't like the tea, you get a free jar !
What the bloody hell can you do with that?
Did I give you a diary?
I can't remember if I did cos I've been picking them up.

pause.w: Every time I go int bank they, just leave them on t' counter, they've been there weeks and weeks.

s.w: And normally, they're all gone so, and I thought, oh!
I give Maggie one for, today.
Say, you ought to say oh .
Where did you put your bag?
We got about twenty panels at work and on the panel there's a little plastic thing stuck on and it needs four keys and one.
So now it hasn't got nowt with it?

ptr.w: There's no keys, there's no key rings?

s.w: I got the last of them.

pause.w: Er, that were before they come in to our place.

s.w: D'ya know, I ke I've had them in my bag I keep forgetting to give them to anyone.

pause.w: Which one?
See if we can use that?

s.w: No, it's that one, big 'un's in my drawer.
If I did that with my rings, just threw them like that, he'd go absolutely apeshit!
I go to work in them, and I'm pulling cables.
Well you're not working for three days, you've got three days off!
You've got a day off of work, a day, and a day off.
You said, you wanted some money.
Do you know, that's cost me for thirty nine quid!
Well that makes your total to four bags of coal.
Well we'll do twenty quid with that thing.

ptr.w: But I, but I didn't get a meter on.

s.w: Our, our Carole's got a fifty pence meter.
Yeah, well as soon as they get

ptr.w: Don't go saying this a right good crack.

unclear.w: I might have to go for a recall.

s.w: I spend all your money on you and you say no!
I think he's got a cheek!
No it int, because I never ever light it in the morning do I?
it later on so it's ready for you coming in.
We ne'er sit in kitchen with Calor gas on.

pause.w: If I run fridge from there back into conservatory, I could put this there and sit in kitchen and shut the door.

s.w: I thought the fridge were going in cubbyhole?
But somebody put shelves in and everything else and what have you, so it don't fit.
And then, they've just had the gas tank down the full 'un.
Has he got another one in as well, in there?
I've got three gas tanks and they were all empty over Christmas so last time he got paid, I filled two up.
Last time we got them filled we got them from down here, thirty odd quid.

unclear.c: . I gi him a twenty pound note and he give me some change.

ptr.w: Straight across road there's a garage there.

s.w: And it's nine pound, did I say nine pound fifty a tank?

ptr.w: Either nine or nine pound fifty a tank.

s.w: That's where I get it from.
And down here it's thirteen quid.
About thirty nine quid they charged me for three.
Yeah well I get so it's a pound cheaper than I, you know, others I've been going to.

pause.w: I'd go there if I were you.

ptr.w: I'll take one wi you on Saturday.

s.w: I got twenty in my bag cos I haven't got one on other room.

ptr.w: You got paid a month ago.

s.w: I don't know how you work it.
We only have it on one bar, two bar

ptr.w: I sometimes have one on, then I put two on.

s.w: Wait till I'm a bit cold.
I start with three and then, I think, phworgh!
And turn it down to two.
And then, I either leave it like that or turn it to one.
See we I were, I did this morning, I put two on kept door shut.
I thought, it's warm in here.
On a dinner time when I go out on a dinner time I leave it on.
I just leave the one bar on
and then it's right warm when I come in.

pause.w: I've usually got it on when you're here all morning haven't I?

s.w: But so far, that's why I chitted at him this morning about that coal because I've been using this all morning, I've not been lighting fire till between one and three o'clock.
And I have four so far it's four weeks, haven't I?
That's a four, a four, a three, and a three.

ptr.w: And I use the fire too.
Who still haven't got that aspirin have we?

s.w: I says, he won't cos they've been feeding him.

ptr.w: You see, they know him don't they?

s.w: You see, if Bill comes over he has a go at Bill, even though he knows Bill, but because he don't see him that much he has a go at him.

pause.w: they're , and they're not.

s.w: And what we noticed, is, we've got a spring there but what and there's been a trail of coal right up our
I had the two of them for Christmas and it didn't
didn't even last us into New
And I says, I'm not having this!

ptr.w: So I thought, well he knows I know.

s.w: Because I let them know that I know.
Cos I heard Maggie so someone the someone's thieving Kath's coal.
And she's going mad about it!
Well we've locked the bottom half, cos Steve got a lock and we locked the bottom half.
So, gonna have to buy one.
Well Johnny's supposed to have had one that were a fortnight ago.
And I says to Steve, I says, I can't keep affording this!
I says, between the electric and that, I says, thirty nine pound a week, I says, every week, I says, is getting a bit ridiculous!
Cos in that electric meter, I don't know what they've done to it!
I phoned it up and says the fella had been out, you know, they change, update it
every so often, they've got these little card things well they shove them in and it clicks all these numbers up so I used to buy one token

ptr.w: so every fortnight I bought twenty pounds worth.

s.w: Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah yes!

ptr.w: Well, I've got to buy twenty pounds worth one week

s.w: and ten pound week after, and ten pound week after
to last me for one month, because we've got to put it on.

ptr.w: And my bill, like, come in and seventy odd!
